titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Claude Lee Finney Papers

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Manuscripts and Rare Books

repository.corpname: Special Collections Manuscripts and Rare Books

did.unittitle: Claude Lee Finney Papers

userestrict.p: Claude Lee Finney, a noted professor of English at Vanderbilt University, was born November 21, 1896. He attended public schools and Fitzgerald and Clark Preparatory School in Tennessee, and then enrolled in Vanderbilt as a freshman in 1914. Committed to a goal of obtaining a classical education, he majored in Greek and minored in Latin and was graduated in 1918, a Phi Beta Kappa scholar. He continued his studies at Harvard, shifting his attention from the classics to English literature of the Renaissance and Romantic periods. He received his M.A. from Harvard in 1920, and was awarded the Ph.D. in 1922 upon completion of a dissertation examining the influence of Shakespeare on Keats.

Finney’s scholarly research and publications reflect his two main interests in English literature, as he published many reviews and several aritcles on Keats and Shakespeare from 1930 to 1960. The Evolution of Keats’ Poetry, published by Harvard Press in 1936, is Finney’s major work, and it remains a well-known and influential work among scholars as affirmed by its reprinting in 1963. His interest in Keats lead him to collect copies of all the Keats papers extant, a goal that was aided by a friendship with Arthur Houghton of England, a gentleman who in the 1930’s had the largest collection of Keats manuscripts.

Finney’s teaching career is marked by his forty year tenure at Vanderbilt. Before coming to Vanderbilt he served as an instructor of English at the University of Michigan (1922-23) and the University of Iowa (1923-26), and as instructor and assistant professor at the University of Illinois (192637). He came to Vanderbilt as an assistant professor in 1937 and in the course of his career here taught four graduate seminars and one undergraduate Shakespeare course yearly and directed over 100 graduate theses. He was made Professor Emeritus in 1966 and retired from the department one year later.
Claude Lee Finney and Margaret Boillin were married in 1926 and they had five children. Finney resided in Nashville until his death November 20, 1970.
Sources: vols. 22, 23, 48 of the Vanderbilt Alumnus. Department of English, Vanderbilt University
